description: Students learn how gender is perceived, constructed, and experienced in contemporary Norway,
using psychological and sociocultural perspectives to explore topics such as family life, youth
development/empowerment, education, employment, media/advertising, health, and sexuality.
They also examine indigenous SÃ¡mi and immigrant perspectives. Lectures, site visits, and other
field experiences augment scholarly readings and contribute to an understanding of gender
equality as a foundational guiding principle and practice in an increasingly diverse Norwegian
society. Offered alternate years during interim. Apply through International and Off-Campus
Studies. Prerequisites: PSYCH 125 or a course in Nordic Studies, Women's and Gender Studies,
Family Studies, or Sociology/Anthropology, or permission of instructor; PSYCH 241 or PSYCH 249
